Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Physics at UC Davis
Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports the renewal of the physics Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at the University of California - Davis. Each year, the REU program will provide eight to eleven students from around the United States an opportunity to participate in a ten-week summer research program. REU students work closely with a faculty mentor on a ten-week research project in the areas of condensed matter physics, biophysics, complex systems, nuclear physics, high energy physics, and astrophysics. In addition to their specific research project, the students learn from their interactions with faculty, graduate students, and other REU students, and from field trips showing physics-related work in diverse settings. At the end of the program, each participant gives a formal research presentation and presents a written project report that can lead to a peer reviewed publication. Research work is augmented by an array of educational and social activities. These activities allow students to put their research experience in a wider perspective, to build a network of professional contacts, and to develop professional skills in a scientific environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The UC Davis Physics REU program brought 14-15 undergraduates to Davis each summer from 2013 to 2015. Each student worked on a research project in the physics department, alongside graduate students, faculty members, and other researchers. Most of the students had limited opportunities for research at their home institutions; for example, five came from California community colleges and four from the California State University system. Thus in addition to learning from their own projects, students had the chance to experience the environment and scale of a major research university. To help the students prepare for possible graduate work in physics or related fields, we discussed what graduate school is like and how the admissions process works at weekly lunch meetings. We included preparation for the Graduate Record Exam in Physics, a standardized test often required by physics graduate programs. We also stressed that science students are normally paid to attend graduate school, receiving full tuition fellowships as well as a monthly stipend for living expenses. About 2/3 of the students have completed college and enrolled in graduate programs. A few of the remainder are still in college, and most of the rest have technical jobs, often in computer programming. This development of human resources, in the form of students with technical training, is the broader impact of the project.

The intellectual merit of the REU program comes through the students' contributions to their projects, which address important questions in many subfields of physics. Since the timescale for a physics research project is often much longer than the 10 weeks of a single summer program, a student's contribution often becomes one piece of a much larger endeavor. This award enabled students to work on projects from calculating how a proposed new particle might affect the cosmic microwave background signal from the early universe, to studying a material that might be useful in electrical switches thanks to its very abrupt change in electrical resistance, to analyzing a new mode of operation for the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider at Brookhaven. This last example ultimately led to adjustments to the collider which allow exploration of a new energy range. The first two examples, as well as several other projects, led to research publications. The REU students were often involved in this presentation stage as well, writing sections of research papers and giving talks on the work at conferences.
